transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Good afternoon everyone. Let’s begin. Today we are covering a concept called growth mindset. Growth mindset means that abilities can improve with effort and practice.

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: So it means working harder?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes, effort matters more than talent in many cases. If you practice, you can improve over time.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: Does everyone improve at the same speed?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: No, people improve at different speeds, but improvement is still possible. The brain is like a muscle—the more you use it, the stronger it becomes.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: Sometimes I fail even when I try.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Failure can be part of learning. Learning from failure helps you adjust your strategy and try again.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: There are two types of thinking: fixed mindset and growth mindset. Fixed mindset is believing abilities cannot change, while growth mindset is believing abilities can develop with effort.

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: I usually feel like I’m just not good at science.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: With more practice and different study methods, improvement is possible.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Let’s take a minute to think about one skill you would like to improve this term.

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: Math.

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: Speaking in class.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: Football skills.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Okay. Write down one small action you could take to improve that skill this week.

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: Practice math problems daily.

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: Raise my hand once in class.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Good. Consistent effort is important for improvement.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: What if someone feels discouraged often?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That happens. Sometimes taking short breaks or organizing your schedule better can help you stay on track.

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: My parents always say some people are naturally talented.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Talent exists, but effort still plays a major role. Practicing regularly helps skills develop.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Another example: if you fail a test, instead of thinking 'I’m not smart,' you can think, 'I need to try a different study method next time.'

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: So it’s about changing how we think?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Yes, changing thinking and putting in consistent effort.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: Sometimes I start practicing and then stop after a few days.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That’s common. Creating a simple schedule or reminder can help maintain consistency.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Let’s take another moment and write one challenge you faced recently and what you could try differently next time.

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: I didn’t prepare enough for a quiz.

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: I avoided asking questions when I didn’t understand.

transcript.speaker: Member3
transcript.text: I gave up too quickly when homework was hard.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Trying a different strategy next time may help. Growth mindset focuses on improvement through effort and learning from mistakes.

transcript.speaker: Member4
transcript.text: Does growth mindset mean we should never feel frustrated?

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: No, frustration is normal. The idea is to continue practicing even when something feels difficult.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: Before we finish, remember the key idea: abilities can improve with effort, practice, and learning from failure.

transcript.speaker: Member2
transcript.text: Okay.

transcript.speaker: Member5
transcript.text: That makes sense.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: For this week, try putting extra effort into one challenging subject and observe whether you notice gradual improvement.

transcript.speaker: Member1
transcript.text: Alright.

transcript.speaker: Member6
transcript.text: I’ll try that.

transcript.speaker: Fellow
transcript.text: That concludes today’s session. We will continue with another topic next time.
